name: Timid
title: Minimalist, Privacy-First Web Browser
tagline: No ads. No tokens. Just privacy.

background.headline: Web Browsing Shouldn't Monetize You
background.summary: Most browsers now double as ad platforms, analytics trackers, or crypto marketplaces—leaving users uncertain where privacy actually ends and business begins.
background.insight: Timid rebuilds browsing around true privacy, stripping out all monetization, reward schemes, and data collection. It focuses on clean, unmonetized speed, and minimalism.

structuralChallenges: Most browsers ship with hidden monetization layers, ad code, or engagement rewards.
Data collection is disguised as 'telemetry' or 'opt-in analytics'.
Default settings often leak identifiers and browsing patterns.
Privacy features are replaced with complex opt-outs rather than defaults.
Users must trust centralized code or servers that can't be verified.
Open-source code is common, but open governance and transparency are neglected.

marketOpportunity.insight: Privacy-first users, open-source advocates, and professionals are seeking browsers that simply do their job, without surveillance or rewards.
dataPoints: Millions of users search for alternatives to ad-driven browsers every year.
Open source browsers grow fastest when transparency and minimalism are clear.
Community-led browser forks can attract rapid adoption if they eliminate business-driven code.

solution.headline: Transparent, Unmonetized Browsing
solution.description: Timid is built directly from open-source browser code, stripped end-to-end of monetization, rewards, and data tracking. No telemetry, no crypto, no engagement distractions—just security, speed, and privacy.

coreFeatures.title: No Monetization Code
coreFeatures.text: Removes all ad, tracking, and backend monetization logic by default.

coreFeatures.title: Hard Privacy Defaults
coreFeatures.text: Tracking protection, fingerprint resistance, and HTTPS everywhere from the start—no opt-ins, no exceptions.

coreFeatures.title: Open Source, Always
coreFeatures.text: Fully transparent code and build scripts, with plain documentation about every change and removal.

coreFeatures.title: Upstream Security Updates
coreFeatures.text: Fast security patches inherited directly from Chromium's open-source codebase.

coreFeatures.title: Minimalist UI
coreFeatures.text: A clean, distraction-free interface that doesn't push 'rewards' or analytics popups.

coreFeatures.title: Community Governance
coreFeatures.text: Visible, auditable commits and changelogs; contributor-friendly onboarding.

comparative.title: Before vs After: Conventional Browsers vs Timid

items.traditional: Ads, trackers, and reward schemes embedded by default.
items.timid: No ads, reward tokens, or tracking code anywhere.
Hard privacy defaults—tracking and fingerprinting blocked from install.

items.traditional: Hidden analytics sent to vendor servers.
items.timid: No telemetry or anonymous usage metrics collected, ever.
Open governance—every critical change explained and documented.

items.traditional: Opaque code paths and unclear incentives.
items.timid: Direct, transparent code. Blunt documentation of what's removed.

vision.title: Strategic Vision: Honest and Simple Browsing

principles.title: Privacy First, By Default
principles.description: Privacy isn't optional or opt-in—it's baked in and documented from the start.

principles.title: Minimalism Over Monetization
principles.description: Browsers should focus on speed, security, and user experience—not monetizing attention.

principles.title: Transparency Over Hype
principles.description: Every feature and removal is plainly documented and auditable.

principles.title: Community Before Brand
principles.description: Open-source ethics and transparency drive contribution—not flashy branding.

vision.summary: Timid delivers honest, efficient web browsing for users tired of hype and hidden agendas.

expectedImpact: Zero revenue from ad, token, or reward code; focus solely on user adoption and transparency.
Up to 30% faster page loads without ads, rewards, or analytics.
Direct code contributions from privacy advocates and professionals.
Rapid security patch adoption due to upstream sync.

whyNow: Growing backlash against monetized browsers and surveillance.
Community and individual users demanding honest, open tools.
Open-source workflows now support automated sync and patching at scale.
If privacy is the product, it shouldn't be sold.
sources: User audits and browser market research
